poem:
### Down Coats

Amid winter's breath,  
a hushed embrace, our  
feathers form comfort,  
defying frost's grasp.  
We drift through  
streets encased,  
puffed clouds,  
a warmth retold.  

Invisible layers speak,  
mute conversations—the art  
of keeping warmth seen  
and felt. Beneath,  
a forgotten summer,  
coats whisper  
stories of snow's dance.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "How did down coats become a fashion staple? Summer dressing is all about linen, swimwear and sandals. Autumn style mostly consists of corduroy trousers, knitwear and boots. In winter, the only part of any outfit that most people will see – ergo the only element that really matters – is the coat. And for the coldest days, only the warmest, most cosseting down coat will do. Not so long ago, wearing a down coat would". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
